posts.title: Trivial Security is hard at work (or hardly working?)

posts.html:
Trivial Security will be bringing a new type of threat monitoring service.

There are undoubtedly a lot of security tools available, It's become something far beyond market saturation, that there isn't a word extensive enough to describe it appropriately.

Which platforms should you invest in? what point solutions are you looking at buying? Just how many individual subscripts and licenses will be needed to have 1 of everything you need to cover off the basics in identifying and managing threats to your organisation?

Trivial Security aims to provide a set of capabilities to any businesses that have no budget for dedicated security employees or 50+ security products. Our solution does not try to be best of breed, it will not be comparable to any point solution with a subscription or any large platforms that demand an annual license fee. It will allow business who could never afford these to finally have one product that is good enough in all areas that they can rest easier with the knowledge Trivial Security has their back.

Knowing almost everything is much better than not knowing nothing at all. And many businesses know less than nothing about their attack surface. They also do not have any continuously monitoring, or somebody to give them verified and specific recommendations on what needs to be done.

Trivial Security aims to remove the jargon so security is approachable to business owners. Recommendations don't simply advise you need to patch if that is the vendor recommendation, so each patch is of course offered and Trivial Security will help you decide if the recommendation is feasible by verifying the vendor recommendation or hand writing a more helpful remediation that suits the specific situation.

We've received feedback that our growing list of integrations are equally valuable to large teams of security professionals that have many other critical tasks to focus on that the millions of small easy things they could be doing are getting missed.

For a business that has no integrations, they may share limited use leveraging the Trivial Security default integrations with third parties, but if you have your're own accounts with the third parties you may directly connect your Trivial Security tenant to get full use of that integration with only limitations associated with your own paid plan

We have currently added 37 integrations in areas of; threat intelligence, open source intelligence, asset discovery, and vulnerability scanners.

Because Trivial Security aims to cover a much larger, even vast, area than current threat monitoring and attack surface management tools have provided - we plan to work with these platforms to ingest their vulnerability findings into Trivial Security or we will publish our findings into theirs.

The cooperation between organisations will of course rely on open standards for data exchange formats. If the proprietary nature of the existing attack surface management tools do not wish to embrace an open standard format then we plan to be transparent with our customers and inform them that the integration is being blocked by them and Trivial Security will enable the integration when the proprietary platform decide to empower their customers and publish customer data as interchangeable open standards data formats.

Supported formats

Current:

  • OVAL - for patches, and preferred for bespoke vulnerabilities
  • UVI - preferred common vulnerabilities format
  • CVE - legacy but still common
  • CWE - limited value, important companion if CVE is used
  • CPE - crucial for asset discovery
  • Zonefile - DNS
  • RSS2.0 - strongly discouraged, only Amazon AWS are using it
  • Simple domain name / IPv4 / IPv6 per line
  • YARA

In the works:

  • OpenChain Specification 2.0 (SBOM) ISO/IEC 5230:2020
  • STIX

Possible candidate formats:

  • Sigma
  • OpenTPX
  • GENE
  • MISP

More details to come
posts.plaintext:
Trivial Security will be bringing a new type of threat monitoring service.

There are undoubtedly a lot of security tools available, It's become something
far beyond market saturation, that there isn't a word extensive enough to
describe it appropriately.

Which platforms should you invest in? what point solutions are you looking at
buying? Just how many individual subscripts and licenses will be needed to have
1 of everything you need to cover off the basics in identifying and managing
threats to your organisation?

Trivial Security aims to provide a set of capabilities to any businesses that
have no budget for dedicated security employees or 50+ security products. Our
solution does not try to be best of breed, it will not be comparable to any
point solution with a subscription or any large platforms that demand an annual
license fee. It will allow business who could never afford these to finally have
one product that is good enough in all areas that they can rest easier with the
knowledge Trivial Security has their back.

Knowing almost everything is much better than not knowing nothing at all. And
many businesses know less than nothing about their attack surface. They also do
not have any continuously monitoring, or somebody to give them verified and
specific recommendations on what needs to be done.

Trivial Security aims to remove the jargon so security is approachable to
business owners. Recommendations don't simply advise you need to patch if that
is the vendor recommendation, so each patch is of course offered and Trivial
Security will help you decide if the recommendation is feasible by verifying the
vendor recommendation or hand writing a more helpful remediation that suits the
specific situation.

We've received feedback that our growing list of integrations are equally
valuable to large teams of security professionals that have many other critical
tasks to focus on that the millions of small easy things they could be doing are
getting missed.

For a business that has no integrations, they may share limited use leveraging
the Trivial Security default integrations with third parties, but if you have
your're own accounts with the third parties you may directly connect your
Trivial Security tenant to get full use of that integration with only
limitations associated with your own paid plan

We have currently added 37 integrations in areas of; threat intelligence, open
source intelligence, asset discovery, and vulnerability scanners.

Because Trivial Security aims to cover a much larger, even vast, area than
current threat monitoring and attack surface management tools have provided - we
plan to work with these platforms to ingest their vulnerability findings into
Trivial Security or we will publish our findings into theirs. 

The cooperation between organisations will of course rely on open standards for
data exchange formats. If the proprietary nature of the existing attack surface
management tools do not wish to embrace an open standard format then we plan to
be transparent with our customers and inform them that the integration is being
blocked by them and Trivial Security will enable the integration when the
proprietary platform decide to empower their customers and publish customer data
as interchangeable open standards data formats.

Supported formats
Current:

 * OVAL [https://oval.cisecurity.org/repository] - for patches, and preferred
   for bespoke vulnerabilities
 * UVI [https://github.com/cloudsecurityalliance/uvi-database] - preferred
   common vulnerabilities format
 * CVE [https://github.com/CVEProject/cve-schema] - legacy but still common
 * CWE [https://cwe.mitre.org/documents/schema/schema_v4.3.html] - limited
   value, important companion if CVE is used
 * CPE [https://cpe.mitre.org/specification/] - crucial for asset discovery
 * Zonefile [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zone_file] - DNS
 * RSS2.0 - strongly discouraged, only Amazon AWS are using it
 * Simple domain name / IPv4 / IPv6 per line
 * YARA [https://yara.readthedocs.io/]

In the works:

 * OpenChain Specification 2.0
   [https://github.com/OpenChain-Project/Specification/tree/master/Official] 
   (SBOM) ISO/IEC 5230:2020
 * STIX
   [https://oasis-open.github.io/cti-documentation/stix/gettingstarted.html]

Possible candidate formats:

 * Sigma [https://github.com/Neo23x0/sigma/wiki/Specification]
 * OpenTPX [https://github.com/Lookingglass/opentpx/]
 * GENE [https://github.com/0xrawsec/gene]
 * MISP [https://github.com/MISP/misp-objects]

More details to come
